Award.AwardTitle: Causes and Consequences of Variation in cyclic AMP - Protein Kinase A Signaling in Yeast

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Few detailed studies have been conducted on the influence of genetic variation on signal transduction pathways, even though knowledge of this is important to the understanding of cell behavior. The cyclic adenosine monophosphate-protein kinase A (cAMP-PKA) signaling pathway is conserved in animals and fungi and regulates cellular growth and differentiation. For example, in yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) cAMP-PKA signaling plays a central role in regulating developmental transitions such as the shift from typical yeast form growth to filamentous growth and the formation of biofilms. The goal of this project is to develop and use fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET)-based sensors to characterize how signaling in the yeast cAMP-PKA pathway varies with genetic background and environmental stimuli, and the manner in which this affects cellular growth and differentiation.

Broader Impacts. This project will support the training and mentoring of postdoctoral, undergraduate and high school trainees. It will also support a continuing outreach project lead by the PI that provides a week-long course on microbiology and systems biology to advanced high school students. The PI will use materials from this outreach course to develop on-line science investigation modules that will be made available to high school science educators at the state and national level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop improved assays for studying the behavior of a signaling network called the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) - protein kinase A (cAMP-PKA) pathway. The cAMP-PKA pathway is a conserved signaling pathway that is important for the regulation of growth, development, and cellular differentiation in animals and fungi.  Improving the ability to measure variation in cAMP signaling will facilitate new studies into the molecular basis of cellular physiology and pathogensis in yeast and other fungi.  This project considered two different strategies for developing a better cAMP assay: 1) improving an existing biochemical assay to be used with smaller sample volumes and with more simultaneous samples; 2) adopting an existing bioluminescent reporter protein, that had previously been succesfully used in mammalian cells, for in vivo or in vitro use in yeast.  Attempts to optimize the bioluminescent reporters for the smaller cellular volumes and unique physiology of yeast cells were unsuccesful. However, the investigators were able to implement optimizations of the existing biochemical assay to permit higher-throughput analyses.  The optimized biochemical assay was used to study variation in cAMP signaling for a genetically diverse set of yeast strains, that differ in their pathogenic potential and ability to respond to cellular stress. In addition to the improved assay, the investigators also: 1) discovered previously unrecognized differences in the role that cAMP signaling plays in the regulation of cellular differentiation in two closely related yeast species, thus providing novel insight into the evolution of this pathway; and 2) developed a novel single-cell microscopic assay for measuring growth and physiological stress in yeast.  


The broader impact of this project was to enhance an ongoing high-school outreach activity on the topic of "Microbial Stress Responses" that the investigator offers each spring at the North Carolina School of Science and Math.  This outreach activity provides teaching and research opportunities in biological and mathematical sciences for 10-12 high school students per year.
